p.s: To analyze Amir's behaviour and attitudes in this scene one must first take a closer look at the general information we have on him.
Amir Kapoor is the main character of Disgraced, Scene 3.
He is of South Asian origin and grew up in a traditional muslimMuslim family.
It is revealed in the play that his family was deeply antisemeticantisemitic as he wasn't allowed to see his crush who was jewishJewish when he was 10.
Because Amir could not identify himself with the Islam he turned his back in Islam and now talks derogatory about it.
Because of his job as a lawyer at the Jewish law firm Bernstein, Leibowitz (...) he changed his name so that he would not sound muslimMuslim.
He is very invested in his work and determined to become a partner of the law firm he is working for.
That feeling of always being an outsider and having to achieve everything on his own combined with the feeling of superiority reflects in his behaviour.

His enormous rage when Jory told him that she would be made partner at the law firm is displayed in l. 23f. p. 71: You wait a week to tell me this?And the second I say something you don't even like hearing you walk away from me in the mid fucking sentence.Who are you?.
Amir's character is expressed excellently through that sequence.
It becomes evident by the swear words that he fells superior to Jory.
Another characteristic aspect is that he will become aggressive in order to not show his true feelings which are disappointment and sadness over not getting the job.

The writer also conveys the impression that the relationship between Isaac and Jory is characterised by constant competition that intensified over the course of the past months and that is now finally exploding.
Amir is portrayed as a very ambitious character.
An example for that is his confidence.
On one hand he seems completlycompletely confident in himself which becomes evident as it is impossible for him to imagine an affair between Isaac and Emily what (l. 29 p. 71).
Through his unwillingness to believe that Emily might have been unfaithful her significance to him is expressed.
Amir would rather accuse Jory of making the accusation up: (...) now you try to destroy my marriage (l. 18 p. 72), than believing Emily could have cheated.
That his wife could have cheated would have been too much for his already damaged ego.
Therefore he is in denial and centers all his rage/hurt on Jory who he describes as: You're fucking evil.

By stating: First you try to steal my job (...) After everything that I have done for you? (l. 18 p. 72), it is made clear that Amir does not think Jory deserves the job and that he feels let down by her.

The feeling of being unjustly treated and being more deserving of the job than Jory is further exploited when Amir describes: You have no idea how much of myself I've poured into the place? (...) I still leave the office after you do (l. 22-25).
He contrasts his effort with Jory's and according to him, his is obviously more.
Amir's character is ieniant to use vulgar language and does not shred away from insults such as You're the asshole (l. 33 p. 72), You think you are the nigger (l. 29).
These outbursts support him being an aggressive character.
Another fact that adds to taht impression are the director's note on Amir such as vicious (l. 17) and exploding (l. 22).
When he spits in Isaac's face their relationship is symbolized.
They both despise each other and when Isaac says: There's a reason they call you people animals (l. 1 p. 73) it becomes clear that their relationship is beyond repair.
Amir telling Jory Get out (l. 3 p. 73) shows how he is used to giving orders and other people obeying these orders.
Amir is perceived as being duplicitous (l. 7) which makes you such a good agitator.But it's impossible to trust you (l. 5-10 p. 73).
By not answering that accusation the effect is conveyed that Amir's denial has stopped and that he can see some truth in that.
When Emily consules I'm gonne get you that coffee (l. 20) the fragementfragment of their relationship is revealed.
She cares for him and he is dependenddependent on her admiration.
That could be a reason that Emily is so unhappy in the relationship.
When Amir is by himself (l. 22 p. 73) the audience is shown how Amir sees himself.
All alone.

No family he can depend on because they are all muslimMuslim, no work he can depend on because Jory was made partner, and slowly he comes to the realisation that she also doesn't have a wife to depend on, because she is having an affair.

When Emily comes back he confronts her Are you sleeping with him? (l. 27 p. 73), deeply frightened of the answer, frightened that the last fragementfragment of what is holding up his character is about to vanish.
By calling her Em (l. 25) it is shown that he cares for her.
When Emily finally admits to having slept with Isaac all Amir's frustrations are ausgeladen on her.
Amir hits Emily in the face(l. 5) and uncontrolled violance as brutal as it needs to be in order to convey the discharge of a lifetime of discretly building resentment is put on Emily.
In conclusion one could say that Amir is a character with many conflicts within himself.
He is torn between the man he wants to be and the man he is.
The frustrations he endured through his life, he carries with him every day which results into him being very aggressive.
